events.summary: Alfred Schnittke was born in Engels to a family that could easily fill a genealogy sandwich. With a Jewish father and a German mother, as well as a philologist grandmother, the family tree must have been a sight to behold!

In 1946, young Schnittke found himself in Vienna, where he decided to fall in love with music. After all, who wouldn't want to be transported to a world filled with ghosts, historical links, and highbrow music references like Mozart?
In 1948, the Schnittke family relocated to Moscow. Just think of it as a family road trip, but without the songs and snacks, and certainly more of a 'should we really do this?' vibe!

After spending years holed up with his musical scores, Schnittke completed his graduate work at the Moscow Conservatory in 1961. It's like he finally got his gold star for being a dedicated student – but now with more composing responsibilities!
Around 1972, Schnittke completed his epic First Symphony, which was such a bold move that it somehow ended up on the Soviet bureaucracy's naughty list, much like a misbehaving teenager.

After losing his mother in 1972, Schnittke was inspired to compose his Piano Quintet in her memory. It's like creating a heartfelt gift that costs nothing but emotional energy and a lot of introspection.
On June 18, 1983, Schnittke decided to swap some spiritual baggage and converted to Catholicism, adding a twist of faith to his already complex life story – talk about a plot twist!

In 1985, Schnittke had a stroke and took an unplanned nap in a coma. Upon waking, he must have felt like he had just crashed from a wild party – now with a bit less mobility but still a lot of creativity!
In 1990, seeking a change of scenery and possibly better health, Schnittke moved to Hamburg. It was like finding a hidden room in a house – one that was quieter and more inviting!

Schnittke passed away in Hamburg in 1998, leaving behind a musical legacy that mingles light and heavy like a perfectly balanced dessert. Who needs a life preserver when you can just compose your way to immortality?
Schnittke starts composing at a young age, showcasing works that are as eclectic as a box of chocolates, but with more dissonance. His early pieces hint at the genius that is about to unfold.
After years of dedication, Schnittke graduates from the Moscow Conservatory, officially becoming a 'master of awkward silence' who creates brilliant sounds in between the notes.
Diving into the world of cinema, Schnittke scores his first film, and it turns out to be an adventure — not unlike a rollercoaster, but with an excellent soundtrack.
His 'Concerto Grosso No. 1' makes waves in the music world, swimming upstream against the currents of traditionalism like a rebellious salmon.
Schnittke faces serious health challenges, turning his life into a dramatic opera where he plays the leading role — if only he could score it better!
With spirits high, Schnittke returns to composing, proving that even a composer can pull off a 'comeback tour' without the glitter—just lots of notes!
Schnittke achieves international acclaim, becoming a household name among music lovers and just about anyone who has ever tried to explain polystylism at a party.
